Speaker: Mr MARTYR
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I have some a good news for the House tonight. We have just listened to a lot of nonsense from the honourable member for Burke (Mr Keith Johnson). The good news that I have to give the House tonight is that the Victorian Government has denied to the Australian Conservation Foundation the $5,000 that it has been accustomed to receive. is the best news that I have heard. I want the to be acquainted with this matter, particularly honourable members opposite. The people with this foundation, in my judgment, is have been responsible for some of the worse the industrial sabotage that we have seen in this country in the last 5 years. They are holding up aU uramum development. They are holding up the Newport power house and now, it is announced, they will see what they can do to stop I really the old Newport power house. I wonder how honourable members in Victoria and the people of Victoria are going to get any power whUe this sort of action is tolerated. I that the Victorian Government has set a lead for Australia in isolating the Australian Conservation Foundation for what it is-a n saboteur holding up all industrial development in Australia. I hope that the Federal Government-ou r Government-wil l have a look at the Australian Conservation Founa posdation because it also subsidises that in this chamber. organisation. Every piece of data that it produces works against everything that we are trying to do in stirring the economy, in stimulating people and in trying to get the sons of things that are going to be necessary in the future for providing employment. I hope that our Government takes a serious look at any allocation that it is thinking of making to the Austrahan Conservation Foundation. They are not all communists. I have said that on other occasions. Unfortunately they are people of the 'do good' variety who do not know a great deal about what is necessary for the development of this economy, particularly in terms of power needs. I am afraid that these people are being led by the nose by elements which I can only describe as sinister. If any honourable member wants to have a look at a current issue of the Communist publication called Arena he will see the clear delineation of what the communists and the marxists consider necessary to hold up this country. I draw the attention of the House to this most imponant matter.

Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being 11 p.m. the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjourned until 2.15 p.m. on Tuesday next. House adjourned at 11 p.m. The following answers to questions Tax Deductability of Mortgage Interest Rates Dr Jenkins asked the Teasurer, upon nodce: (1) What projections have been carried out to determine the number of taxpayers who will be deprived of tax deductibility of mortgage interest rates as a result of the Govern28 ment's decision to confine the benefit to first home buyers in their first 5 years. (2) Is it a fact that over half a million taxpayers could therightof tax deduction. (3) Does the Government anticipate a net saving in excess of $200m in the 3 years preceding Savings Grant Scheme by denial of tax concessions to existCPI increaseofinwage ing eligible home buyers. Mr Lynch-The answer to the honourable Commission member's question is as follows: (1) and (2) Estimates based on income tax statistics of housing loan interest allowed for the 1974-75 income year indicate that the number of taxpayers who will lose access to tax deductibility of such interest as a result of the decision confine the benefits to first home buyers in the first five of use of the home would be over half a million. (3) The gain to revenue of the restrictions on deductibility is estimated to be about $40m per annum. Mr Les MCMahon asked the Treasurer, upon notice: (1) Is it the intention of the Government to reduce real wages by persuading the Arbitrauon only half wage indexation. (2) If so, would this result in substantially reduced income tax receipts and thereby increase the deficit. (3) If it is still the intention of the Government to reduce the deficit, why is it advocating action that would have opposite effect. Mr Lynch-The answer to the honourable these member's question is as follows: (1) In the April hearing of the National Wage Case-th hearing to which the honourable member's question was clearly addressed-the Commonwealth twelve-month period the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should award indexation increases which, having regard to additions to the total wages bill, would amount something like 50 per cent of full indexation. With regard the form of indexation, the Commonwealth's option during the period was that each award rate should be increased by a flat amount arrived at by applying to the minimum wage and full price increase in the reference period, discounted for any increase in indirect taxes (or major increases in import prices) occurring in that period. Had the Government's approach Commission it would, all other things being equal, have had the effect of gradually reducing those real wages above the minimum wage from the inflated level previously risen and which lay turn in activity and growth in unemployment which the economy experienced in 1974 and 1975. NA upon notice were circulated: It is estimated that, had the Government's submission been accepted in full by the Commission, real earnings (Question No. 397) would, on average, have been reduced by between 1 and 1.5 per cent by the December quaner 1976 provided there was litde intensification of wages drift. In the event the decision of the Commission announced on May was equivalent to about 70 per cent of full indexation overall. It therefore had the effect of reducing real wages of those wage and salary earners who at the time of the decision were receiving awards of more than $125 per weeklose that is, to a lesser extent than the Government's preferred option would have involved. Since then a further National Wage Case, to consider the payments under the Home application indexation on account of 2.5 per cent the June quaner, has concluded. In this recent hearing, too, the Commonwealth has urged on the that it grant only partial wage indexation in the interest of a further and speedier winding down in the rate of inflation, to ensure that the process of economic recovery just beginning is in no way thwarted or truncated, and to reverse the past tendency for Australian labour costs to increase faster than the labour costs of our major trading partners. In the to Commonwealth's submission the desirable option would years now have been a wage increase equivalent to something like 30 per cent of full indexation. The Commission's decision, announced on 12 August, was equivalent to a little under 70 per cent of full indexation overall. This implies some reduction in real wages for all Wage Indexation wage and salary earners receiving awards of more than $ 100 (Question No. 493) per week, but as in May not as much reduction as the Government had sought. (2) The National Wage Case decision of 28 May did not have a significant bearing on the Budget aggregates for 1975-76 but will have a 'full year' effect on the Budget estiCommission to award mates for 1976-77. (3) The Government's fundamental aim in economic policy is to wind back the rate of inflation. This cannot be achieved solely through reductions in the level of the deficit. It is necessary to combat inflation on all fronts, including the fiscal, monetary and wages pohcy. Although the Government's approach to wages policy would have gone further than the Commission's decisions of 28 May and 12 August, decisions represented worthwhile steps towards winding down the current rate of inflation of costs and prices and will, it is hoped, through their effects on the inflationary exe pectations both of business and of consumers, assist in the recovery of economic activity and the creation of job submitted that for a opportunities. It would be a curious argument indeed, if the effects of to some economic policies on the deficit were to be used as an to argument against attempting to reduce the current rate of preferred inflation. Destruction of Cargo (Question No. 847) Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Health, been adopted by the upon notice: Will he supply full details of the reasons for quarantine staff recently destroying a number of cartons at Bruck MUls, to which they had Wangaratta, Victoria. at the root of the sharp down

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Following the discovery of Khapra beetle in the 'Catherine S', all cargo that had been located in the infested holds was traced and inspected. A consignment of viscose yarn from one of these holds had been delivered to Bruck Mills, Wangaratta. On inspection at the premises, one larva and two cast skins were found in the wrapping. The wrapping and cartons were destroyed and the area sprayed. Industries Assistance Commission Reports Mr Lloyd asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice: (1) Where the economic information originally submitted to an Industry Assistance Commission hearing relevant at the time of presentation of the draft report, is the Commissioner required to accept updated information. (2) If so, and when a Commissioner information to be presented, or to consider it in his repon, what action can be taken. (3) Has there been unhappiness with the Commission over recommendadons it makes to the Government based on outdated cost, price and impon or export data.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) One of the reasons for producing draft reports cussing these reports at public nesses to present any later information they had and considered relevant. Commissioners are not compelled to accept specific pieces of they normally try to obtain as much relevant information as is available up to the time at which they sign the There must, however, be a point ticable to receive further information. This is particularly so where the Commission's reports are subject to reporting deadlines. (2) See answer to question (1). (3) I am not aware of any such unhappiness. Mr Garrick asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice: (1) Has his attention been drawn to newspaper reports urging Federal action on the youth unemployment problem. (2) Can he say whether the Deputy Principal of the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology has offered facilides for a conference on this matter. (3) As people younger than 20 years old comprise 12 per cent of the workforce but almost 40 per cent of the unemployed, will he look into such offers and the problems which giveriseto them. Mr Street-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. It is a matter which is of great concern to Government. I have asked my Department to do all it can within existing programs and resources to stimulate employ the ment opportunities for young people and to assist them in every way to find employment. The need for addidonal Government initiatives is being closely examined by my panment within the context of the Government's overall economic strategy. (2) I understand that the Acting Melbourne Institute of Technology offered the use of its facilities for a public meeting which was held on 31 August 1976. The meeting considered the problems of youth unemployment. My Department was represented at the meeting. (3) Yes. The honourable member can be assured that appropriate initiatives taken by the community will receive ready cooperation and assistance from my Depanment. Whitlam asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relauons, upon notice: How did the Australian Government delegates vote on the instruments adopted at the Sixty-First (1976) Session of the is no longer International Labour Conference. G. Whitlam asked the Minister for Emreports. ployment and Industrial Relauons, upon notice: beyond which it is not prac(1) What order of priority did the Commonwealth and State Labour Ministers set in 1973 for their consideration of unratified ILO Conventions involving State jurisdiction (Hansard, 24 August 1976, page 517). (2) Which of those Conventions have they since considered, and on what dates, in what form and with what result. Unemployment (Question No. 987) Mr Street-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The Commonwealth and State Labour Ministers agreed in 1973 that unratified ILO Conventions involving State jurisdiction and warranting further consideration should be divided into the following order of priority: (a) top priority-wher e the aim is to ratify as quickly as possible and includes Conventions which deal with questions of very important principle. (b) priority-wher e ratification at an early stage is the objective though considerable action may be required including new policy initiatives. (c) keep under review-wher e ratification is a longer term objective and there may be extensive technical problems to be overcome. (2) International labour matters including ILO Conventhe tions is a standing item on the agenda of the twice yearly meetings of Commonwealth and State Labour Ministers. As honourable member will be aware, the Ministers' meetings are the third tier of the Commonwealth/State consultative machinery on ILO matters and the Ministers consider Derecommendations which come forward from the other 2 tiers of the machinery: the technical officers (ie ILO action officers) and Permanent Heads of the Commonwealth and Principal of the Royal State Departments. The consultative machinery has devoted its attention principally to those Conventions allocated to the top priority category. In 1973 the Ministers agreed that the following Conventions should be accorded top priority for ratification: No. 81-Labou r Inspection, 1947 No. 100-Equa l Remuneration, 1951 No. 107-Indigenou s and Tribal Populations, 1957 No. 119-Guardin g of Machinery, 1963 No. 135-Workers'Representatives , 1971 Since then Australia has ratified Conventions Nos 81 (24.6.75) and 100 (10.12.74) and early ratification of Convention No. 107 is dependent upon the agreement of one State. As regards Conventions Nos 119 and 135, some progress has been made but further progress is required before Australia will be in a position to ratify. The operation of the consultative machinery has made a positive contribution towards the improvement of, Australia's ratification record of ILO Conventions and to the promotion of the acceptance of international labour standards in Australia. At their most recent meeting (3 September 1976), the Ministers decided that their officers should review the order of priority agreed upon in 1973.
